sectionTitle: Some Special Cases of Discounted Cash Flow Analysis

columns.text: In this problem, we will interpret the net present value and the equivalent annual cost.

**a.** The bid price refers to the price that the buyer has set to acquire a certain item or project. Calculating the appropriate bid price is essential so that you won't overpay for the project and at the same time, you can have a competitive price against the other bidders.

The benchmark used in calculating the bid price is the zero net present value of the project. It is important to recall that the net pressure value is the difference between the project's cash inflow and its outflow. A positive net present value indicates a profitable project while a negative net pressure value indicates the opposite.

The importance of using the zero net present value is because this is the minimum amount before the project becomes unprofitable. The zero net present value is the break even point of the project so setting the price near this is the best move in setting a bid price.

**b.** Unequal economic lives happens when two projects have different cash flows. This can be worrying since one project may not be as profitable as the other which may lead to losses in the future. To help decide which project is better, the equivalent annual cost is used.
**10.6a** For this question, we will explain why a bid price of zero net present value is a reasonable measurement that may be made.

The total present value of a project's cash flows is its net present value (NPV). The NPV will be positive if all of the cash flows are positive. The NPV will be negative if all of the cash flows are negative. We are only interested in initiatives with positive net present values. As a result, we should utilize a zero NPV as our benchmark because it indicates that the present value of all cash flows is zero. This indicates that the project will make a profit. If all other factors are equal, projects with larger NPVs are more worthwhile investments since they provide greater future returns potential.
**10.6b** The question asks us to define what the EAC is and what we should be concerned about in terms of unequal economic lives.

Uneven economic lives become an issue in a few important scenarios. One example is when economic inequity results in unequal access to opportunities and resources required for economic security and success. Another example is when economic disparities make it difficult for certain people to achieve the same levels of prosperity and security as others. The Equal Access to Credit and Trade Act (EAC) tries to solve these challenges by promoting equal access to credit and commerce, which can assist to minimize economic inequality.
